channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Letter from China: A Race Against Time for a Second Child
item.description: Zhejiang Province has become the first to implement legal changes permitting many couples to have two children, after decades of only one. But elsewhere the wait is agonizing for many couples whose biological clock is ticking.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Although a relaxation in the one-child policy has been announced, laws have yet to be changed in many localities.

item.title: Egypt Charges Renowned Scholar With Espionage
item.description: Emad Shahin, a political scientist, was charged along with senior leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood with conspiring to undermine Egypt’s security.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Report Says China’s Elite Use Offshore Companies
item.description: Leaked documents show that thousands of wealthy, well-connected Chinese have set up companies in tax-haven countries to hold assets, an investigative reporting group says.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Israeli Airstrike Kills 2 in Gaza
item.description: One of the dead was a member of the armed wing of Islamic Jihad, which vowed to retaliate for the Israeli attack.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: The Lede: Video Shows Toronto’s Mayor Using Jamaican Patois in Obscene Rant About Police Surveillance
item.description: Two months after he claimed to have embraced sobriety, Mayor Rob Ford was caught on video Monday complaining about police surveillance of him and his associates in a drunken, obscenity-laced rant.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of a photograph posted on Instagram early Tuesday showing Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto at a fast-food restaurant.

item.title: Lawyers for Chinese Activist Believe Conviction Is Predetermined
item.description: The two lawyers defending Xu Zhiyong were silent in court on Wednesday, saying there was no point waging a legal fight against the prosecution.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: The Lede: Ominous Text Message Sent to Protesters in Kiev Sends Chills Around the Internet
item.description: As the Orwellian text message sent to protesters in Ukraine on Tuesday chills the Internet, it seems worth asking if it is really that unusual.
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER MURPHY
item.media:credit: Andrew E. Kramer/The New York Times
item.media:description: A text message sent to the phones of people close to clashes in the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, on Tuesday read: "Dear subscriber, you are registered as a participant in a mass disturbance."

item.title: Testy Exchange Sets Tone as Peace Talks Open on Syria
item.description: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said his injunction for a constructive dialogue “had been broken” on Wednesday following a lengthy diatribe by the Syrian foreign minister, Walid al-Moallem.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon opens the Geneva peace talks on Syria on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 22
item.description: India celebrates its annual republic day on Jan. 26.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man running with the national flag in Agartala, Tripura. India celebrates its Republic Day on Jan. 26.

item.title: For the First Time, Ukraine Protests Lead to Deaths
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich met with opposition leaders on Wednesday after two protesters were shot to death and a civil uprising edged Kiev, the capital, toward a state of emergency.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: At least two people have died in the fighting between the riot police units, called by their Ukrainian name the Berkut, and protesters.

item.title: The Lede: War Crimes Experts Call Syrian Defector’s Photographs ‘Direct Evidence’ of Assad’s ‘Killing Machine’
item.description: A team of legal and forensic experts concluded that post-mortem photographs, provided to the Syrian opposition by a man who describes himself as a defector from President Bashar al-Assad’s security forces, offer “direct evidence” of torture and execution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: In an Emergency, Call 100. Or is it 1098? Or 103?
item.description: In big Indian cities like Bangalore, the lack of a unified first-responder system and the inability to crack down on crank calls are endangering people who need help quickly.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI

item.title: European Union Lowers Its Ambitions on Renewable Energy
item.description: Bowing to economic realities, the bloc proposed an end to binding national targets for energy production from sustainable energy sources.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Goats grazing near wind turbines in Fantanele and Cogealac villages, Romania.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Web Outage Blamed on Censorship Glitch
item.description: Chinese authorities suggested the massive disruption was the work of hackers. But others cited a malfunction of the government’s Great Firewall, the sprawling, hidden infrastructure used to restrict what ordinary Chinese can see online.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times

item.title: Thai Election Official, at Odds With Leaders, Wants Vote Postponed
item.description: Somchai Srisutthiyakorn, a member of the Election Commission, says he does not think a vote will do anything to resolve the political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Somchai Srisutthiyakorn is one of five members of Thailand’s Election Commission.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Supporters Protest as China Puts Rights Advocate on Trial
item.description: Scores of supporters of Xu Zhiyong flocked to a Beijing courthouse and demonstrated noisily in front of foreign reporters.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Report Details Overseas Accounts of Chinese Elite
item.description: A report divulges new details about the wealth of relatives of some of China’s most powerful leaders.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Relatives of senior Chinese officials, including President Xi Jinping, above, are among those whose overseas holdings are listed in a new report.

item.title: A Leader of Pro-Government Faction Is Shot in Thailand
item.description: Kwanchai Praipana, who runs a group that supports the government, was shot a day after Thailand’s prime minister declared emergency rule.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kwanchai Praipana is a leader of Thailand's pro-government Red Shirts movement.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Author Vikram Chandra
item.description: Mr. Chandra spoke to India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival about the research he did for his 2006 book, “Sacred Games,” its television adaptation and why he calls it an anti-thriller.
item.dc:creator: By AAYUSH SONI
item.media:description: Vikram Chandra, author of the book 'Sacred Games' at the Jaipur Literature Festival on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Military Eyes Afghan Force of 10,000, or a Pullout
item.description: The Pentagon has proposed to President Obama that 10,000 American troops remain in Afghanistan when the international combat mission there ends after this year, or none at all, senior government officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Leader Expresses Support for Abused Maid
item.description: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono joined thousands of Indonesian migrant workers abroad and at home on Tuesday in expressing outrage at the alleged torture of an Indonesian maid by her Hong Kong employer.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican Monsignor Suspected of Money Laundering
item.description: Monsignor Nunzio Scarano, already on trial for plotting to smuggle $26 million from Switzerland to Italy, was arrested Tuesday in a separate case, suspected of using his Vatican bank accounts to launder money.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Photo Archive Is Said to Show Widespread Torture in Syria
item.description: If genuine, the trove is new visual corroboration that Syria’s government is guilty of mass war crimes against its own citizens, just as it appeared to regain some international standing.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Photographs released by lawyers commissioned by the Qatari government, an opponent of Syria’s government, are being portrayed as part of an archive of torture under President Bashar al-Assad. The abuses are said to include “tramline injuries,” linear bruises from being beaten with a rod.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Embassy at the Vatican Will Reopen
item.description: Ireland is reopening its embassy to the Vatican more than two years after shutting it down in the wake of sex abuse cases.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Environment: 2013 Listed as One of the Warmest Years on Record
item.description: Two government agencies said Tuesday that 2013 was among the warmest years in the global temperature record, though they differed on exactly where it ranked.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
